The civilization of Ancient Egypt lasted longer than the entire span of what we have come to accept as 'recorded history': over three thousand years. During these millenia the Egyptians developed a multitude of gods and goddesses, as well as esoteric practices that we are still unravelling the meaning of. Besides this, Egypt was the source of the first true monothestic religion, under the pharaoh Akhenaton. This rich tradition was mostly unknown until the early nineteenth century, when the Egyptian language was finally deciphered.
 Sacred Texts: Ancient Egypt

 Here is a bit from the Stele of Amenmose (Louvre C286), the most complete known description of the Osiris myth before the Hellenistic period (translated in Foster & Hollis 1995). Horus is born to Isis from sexual union with Osiris and is given his father's kingdom:
 
 
7. His sister [Isis, sister of Osiris] served as his protector, drove off the enemies, put a stop to the misdeeds; Removed the Enemy by power of her spell-golden-tongued, her speech cannot fail, Skilled in command, beneficent Isis, who rescued her brother. She searched for him, would not give in to her weariness, wandered about this land in mourning, Would not take rest until she had found him. She made him shade with her feathers, made breeze by fanning her wings; Danced the Dance of Last Mooring for her brother, tempered the weakness of Him who was weary of heart; She received his seed, produced an heir, brought up the child in solitude (the place could not be known); Introduced him, with his arm grown sturdy, into the court of Geb.
 
 8. And the Ennead rejoiced, "Welcome, Horus, son of Osiris, Firm-hearted and true of voice, son of Isis and heir of Osiris!" The Tribunal of Truth assembled for him, the Nine Great Gods and the Lord of All; The Lords of Truth were gathered there, those who turn their backs upon evil. They sat themselves down at the court of Geb to offer the legacy to its rightful owner and the kingship to whom it belonged. And they determined for Horus, his voice was true; and his father's legacy was given to him.

 
 The recto of P. Chester Beatty I, dating to the reign of Ramses V, gives a very detailed account of Horus' battles with Seth:
 
 Horus is given the kingdom of Osiris, but Seth is upset and wants it for himself (1). Some gods side with Seth, others with Horus, and it is decided by Banebdjede that they'll write to the goddess Neith who'll decided between them (2). Neith says Horus will get the office, and Seth will get the goddesses Anat and Astarte. This doesn't go over well with Re, and together with the Ennead, the nine great gods, he questions Horus and Seth individually. Seth lays out the reasons why he thinks he should get the kingdom -- some gods again agree, thinking Horus too young, and others dissent, thinking that as Osiris' son, it should naturally fall to him. Horus says that his birthright should not stolen from him, and Isis speaks in his defense. (3-5). All the gods go over the Island in the Midst, and Isis changes herself into a beautiful young woman who Seth lusts after. In this form she tells him a story about being the wife of a herdsman who died and whose son was tending the cattle in his place. Another man, she said, came and told the boy that he would take the cattle and drive him out. To this Seth dsif that it was only proper that the son should receive the cattle. Isis transformed again, and Seth realized that he had just confessed the immorality of his own position (5-8). Atum gives the crown to Horus, but Seth won't give up. He challenges Horus; they will turn into hippos, submerge themselves, and whoever comes up out of the water before three months are through will not get the crown. Isis is worried for her son and tries to kill Seth with a harpoon, but releases it from him when he cries out. When she relents, Horus is himself upset and cuts off Isis' head. The Ennead set off to punish him, but Seth finds him first, cuts out his eyes, and buries them. Hator finds him blind and weeping and heals his sight with milk (8-11). The Ennead tell them to stop the constant fighting, settle down and feast together. Seth then invites Horus to a meal, gets sexually aroused, and humps Horus between his thighs. Horus takes Seth's semen and shows Isis, who cuts off his hand, throws the hand into a river, makes him a new one, puts ointment on his penis, fluffs him up and collects his semen in a pot. She then goes off to Seth's garden, pours Horus' semen on Seth's food who then eats it and becomes pregnant with Horus' child. The Ennead call them again, and Seth reports that the kingdom should be his because he has used Horus sexually. They call the semen of both men to witness, and it is learned that Seth's semen is in the river while Horus' is in Seth (11-13). Seth then challenges him to a boat race, which Horus again wins. They finally exchange letters with Osiris, who is naturally upset for his son's plight, and Seth is bound by the orders of Atum. In chains, Seth can only agree that Horus is the true heir, and Osiris' son is subsequently crowned. Isis and the Ennead rejoice (13.16).

 Actually, if you look at the history about WHY Christmas is celebrated on Dec 25th, that is when Constintine declared it should be. It was replacing another Roman holiday that had been declared by a previous emperor (Sol Invictus).
 Diocletian was into the cult of Mithra, and that was one of their major holidays. He declared it a national holiday in 307 AD.
 
 Note: When the Julian calender was adopted in 48 A.D, December 24th was the shortest day of the year, and the 25th is when the sun started 'returning'. 
 
 The first time the date for the 'birth of Jesus' was mentioned to be Dec 25th was a roman calender in 336 A.D. 
 
 Having Dec 25th for the birth of Jesus just is not biblical at all.

 Golly Accipiter, you can hardly follow a written conversation, let alone think clearly about it's contents. Did I ever say that I believed in the truth and accuracy of the bible? What does that even mean? You claimed you have read my past posts; did you notice the thread on biblical errancy? Could this instead mean that I incorrectly accept the truth of some parts of the bible? Well of course I do, as does everyone with an even cursory understanding of the subject material, but I certainly never said anything like that in the thread thus far.
 
 Nor do I recall "coming to the defense of the bible." That you equate my reluctance to accept unsourced internet copypasta with (presumably) Christian apologetics reveals an awful lot more about you than it does me, namely, that you think atheism is synonymous with beliving dumb things without evidence. And who else, Accipiter, believes dumb things without evidence? Whose a priori commitment to certain positions keeps them from looking at data and ignoring it when it disagrees with them?
 
 Fundamentalists, Accipiter. You're a thoughtless, knee-jerk fundie defending his faith.
 
 Now, to ignore with you.

Actually, if you look at the history about WHY Christmas is celebrated on Dec 25th, that is when Constintine declared it should be. It was replacing another Roman holiday that had been declared by a previous emperor (Sol Invictus).
 Diocletian was into the cult of Mithra, and that was one of their major holidays. He declared it a national holiday in 307 AD.
 
 Note: When the Julian calender was adopted in 48 A.D, December 24th was the shortest day of the year, and the 25th is when the sun started 'returning'. 
 
 The first time the date for the 'birth of Jesus' was mentioned to be Dec 25th was a roman calender in 336 A.D. 
 
 Having Dec 25th for the birth of Jesus just is not biblical at all.

 
 Such is the case for numerous Christian holidays--the timing of Resurrection Sunday every year has nothing to do with the scriptures either. 
 But it's important to note that the Church doesn't generally ascribe that these dates are meant to coincide with 'when' an event actually took place. It's rather the date set aside to celebrate said event. Christmas celebrates the Incarnation of Christ. 
 An analogy would be Memorial day in the U.S. It doesn't represent the actual date of any particular war, but is a day of remembrance of the fallen in war. An actual date isn't really pertinent.
Jo Bennett

Such is the case for numerous Christian holidays--the timing of Resurrection Sunday every year has nothing to do with the scriptures either. 

 
 I disagree, it's based on the reckoning of the Jewish lunar calendar, and when the Passover fell. It's modified a bit from that, but it's wrong to say there is no scriptural connection.
Penfold
Memorial day is rooted in the massive losses of the 1914 -18 war, known as The Great War, the war to end all wars......and generalised since then.
unkerpaulie

Interesting topic. I've looked around for bits and pieces of the story of Horus, and really there isn't a lot of similarity between him and Jesus. He was born on Dec 25th, the day that christians celebrate Jesus' birthday. The story says that he was a product of immaculate conception, not that his mother was a virgin. And shortly after his birth his mother fled into Egypt to hide him because Set was looking to kill him. 
 
 I haven't found anything else about the life of Horus that resembles that of Jesus, but then again I'm not an expert on Egyptian mythology so maybe there's more that I haven't found yet. 
 
 From what I've found so far, it might be arguable that some of the events surrounding Jesus' birth were borrowed from that of Horus' birth, but that's where the similarities end. Its reasonable to assume that any events describing Jesus' birth were very likely made up. And I suppose it would make sense to copy the birth events of another savior god that the Mediterranian world was already familiar with.
Art Pigou

Interesting topic. I've looked around for bits and pieces of the story of Horus, and really there isn't a lot of similarity between him and Jesus. He was born on Dec 25th, the day that christians celebrate Jesus' birthday. The story says that he was a product of immaculate conception, not that his mother was a virgin. And shortly after his birth his mother fled into Egypt to hide him because Set was looking to kill him.

 
 What primary source(s) attest to any of the above? 
 
 
From what I've found so far, it might be arguable that some of the events surrounding Jesus' birth were borrowed from that of Horus' birth, but that's where the similarities end. Its reasonable to assume that any events describing Jesus' birth were very likely made up. And I suppose it would make sense to copy the birth events of another savior god that the Mediterranian world was already familiar with.

 
 Even assuming there is evidence for the ostensible parallels above (which I have not seen and seriously doubt exist at all), genetic dependence isn't a better explanation than the alternative. It is well known that the flight to Egypt in Matthew's infancy narrative, for example, is one of several points of contact between Matthew's tradition about Jesus and haggadic legend about Moses. Is it more likely that the Evangelist drew on Jewish tradition, which we are certain he was familar with, to support his conception of Jesus as a new Moses, which we know he believed, or that he was drawing on material about Horus?
Sandycane

'As Sumerian civilization was being worn down by wars and invasions, Egyptian civilization began to rise around 3000 BC. Egypt was protected from attack by the surrounding desert. The Nile River valley was more fertile than Sumeria, allowing two crops to be grown every year. Many aspects of Sumerian culture were adopted by the Egyptians. But unlike Sumeria, which was divided into a number of kingdoms, the whole of Egypt was eventually united under a single king. 
 
 The Egyptians believed in a number of gods and goddesses, some native to their culture, others borrowed from foreign lands. Different communities within the empire followed different religious myths. Most Egyptians recognized at least one god as being the creator of the world. 
 
 Many believed that as they passed into the afterlife, their deeds would be judged by the King of the Dead. The souls of the innocent would be guided to paradise, while the souls of the guilty would be torn to pieces by animal gods and would cease to exist.'
 Shattering the Sacred Myths - The History of Ancient Israel
unkerpaulie

Art, I did a google search for "horus myth". The second result was the wiki page, which mentioned the immaculate conception, and the escape to the nile delta running from set who wanted to kill him as a baby. The fourth result, from philae.nu also describes the same thing. 
 
 As for whether the parallel matches the story of Moses rather than the story of Horus, or whether Mary really fled to Egypt because Herod actually wanted to kill him as a baby, I'm not making any conclusions. I just got tired of everybody arguing about whether the parallels exist without doing the little check required. 
 
 With that in mind, there are lots of other myths that have lots more parallels to Jesus' life than those of Horus.
Art Pigou

Art, I did a google search for "horus myth". The second result was the wiki page, which mentioned the immaculate conception, and the escape to the nile delta running from set who wanted to kill him as a baby. The fourth result, from philae.nu also describes the same thing.

 
 With respect to Isis sheltering Horus, the secondary source cited on Wikipedia, Willis' 'World Mythology' itself cites no primary source, and it's difficult to determine what source, if any, the other website is using. With respect to the "immaculate conception," i'm not sure where you're seeing that on the page. In any event, the "immaculate conception" is a distinctively Christian doctrine pertaining to the conception of Mary without the taint of original sin, something entirely foreign to Egyptian religion.
 
 
As for whether the parallel matches the story of Moses rather than the story of Horus, or whether Mary really fled to Egypt because Herod actually wanted to kill him as a baby, I'm not making any conclusions. I just got tired of everybody arguing about whether the parallels exist without doing the little check required.

 
 My point throughout the whole thread was to avoid exactly what you're doing, namely, making claims about ancient history from cursory internet searches. Conclusions about ancient history are necessarily derived from primary, i.e. ancient, sources, and those invariably turn out to be lacking.
 
 
With that in mind, there are lots of other myths that have lots more parallels to Jesus' life than those of Horus.

 
 And when you say there are "lots of other myths that have lots more parallels to Jesus' life," do you mean you have ancient sources that attest to these parallels, or that you've found websites that claim, without evidence, that such parallels exist?
 
 If it's the former, i'd love to hear them.
unkerpaulie

With respect to Isis sheltering Horus, the secondary source cited on Wikipedia, Willis' 'World Mythology' itself cites no primary source, and it's difficult to determine what source, if any, the other website is using. With respect to the "immaculate conception," i'm not sure where you're seeing that on the page. In any event, the "immaculate conception" is a distinctively Christian doctrine pertaining to the conception of Mary without the taint of original sin, something entirely foreign to Egyptian religion.
 

 I'm using the term immaculate conception to mean impregnating a female in the absence of a physical male partner. In other words, Isis magically got pregnant. From the wiki page: "Horus was born to the goddess Isis after she retrieved all the dismembered body parts of her murdered husband Osiris, except his penis which was thrown into the Nile and eaten by a catfish,[5][6] and used her magic powers to resurrect Osiris and fashion a gold phallus[7] to conceive her son. In another version of the story, Isis was impregnated by divine fire.[8] " Its all under the "Origin mythology" section
 
 
My point throughout the whole thread was to avoid exactly what you're doing, namely, making claims about ancient history from cursory internet searches. Conclusions about ancient history are necessarily derived from primary, i.e. ancient, sources, and those invariably turn out to be lacking.
 

 I suppose you'd be convinced that all secondary or tertiary source accounts of Horus' birth were all made up by all the individual authors of their respective web pages, regardless of how identical they are plot-wise, because they don't reference an original ancient translation in the footnotes? That's your perogative to think so. I think its fair to say that the links found on the internet, unless already flagged as false by another peer, can be generally accepted as correct until proven false. But that's just me. 
 
 
And when you say there are "lots of other myths that have lots more parallels to Jesus' life," do you mean you have ancient sources that attest to these parallels, or that you've found websites that claim, without evidence, that such parallels exist?
 
 If it's the former, i'd love to hear them.

 I don't know if you've heard of the myths of Osiris, Dionysus, Adonis, Attis, and Mithras. They all have numerous characteristics and events that are similar to the accounts of Jesus, and they all predate the gospels. No, I don't have links to ancient original scripts or scrolls, just lots and lots of websites that agree with each other. Sorry to disappoint
Easyrider

I don't know if you've heard of the myths of Osiris, Dionysus, Adonis, Attis, and Mithras. They all have numerous characteristics and events that are similar to the accounts of Jesus, and they all predate the gospels. 

 
 I don't think so. The scholars I've seen who have researched it (Nash, etc. - Is Jesus Myth? Answering More Prime Time Fallacies) say the pagans "christ-like" claims originated after Jesus.
 
 Investigating the Similarities between Jesus and Pagan Figures
